block.p: The Olympics began to look a little like a soap opera, which could only boost NBC's anemic ratings.

First, the French runn Marie-Jose Perec, the defending champion in the women's 200 and 400 meters, said she would not compete and flew to Singapore. Ms. Perec claimed to have been threatened by a man who forced his way into her Sydney hotel room, but Australian newspapers gleefully claimed she was running away from a showdown in the 400 meters with Australian Cathy Freeman. One labeled her ''Mademoiselle La Chicken.''
The Olympics began to look a little like a soap opera, which could only boost NBC's anemic ratings.

First, the French runn Marie-Jose Perec, the defending champion in the women's 200 and 400 meters, said she would not compete and flew to Singapore. Ms. Perec claimed to have been threatened by a man who forced his way into her Sydney hotel room, but Australian newspapers gleefully claimed she was running away from a showdown in the 400 meters with Australian Cathy Freeman. One labeled her ''Mademoiselle La Chicken.''

Next, for the first time in memory, technicians set the vault apparatus at the wrong height for the women's gymnastics, causing Russia's Svetlana Khorkina, then leading in the overall championship competition, to fall. She later fell from the uneven bars as well and, with her chance of a medal gone, refused to vault once more on the readjusted piece of equipment. Afterward, she angrily told reporters to ''get lost.''
